jcr:content.enterSearchTerms: Please enter one or more search terms in the search box above.
jcr:content.noResults: Your search of Entire Site for {{searchTerm}} did not match any documents. Use these search tips to help you find what you're looking for.
jcr:content.noResultsTips:
• Make sure all words are spelled correctly.
  • Use quotes to search for an entire phrase, such as "creative suite master collection"".
  • Try some of these search tips.
jcr:content.searchTips:
Search Tips


Use quotation marks

Use quotation marks to find words that must appear adjacent to each other, such as transparent background. Without quotes, the search results will include the words transparent and background, but not necessarily in that order (i.e., the words may appearanywhere, in any order, within the document).


Use plus (+) or minus (-)

Use a plus sign when your search term or phrase must appear in the search results. Use aminus sign to indicate undesirable term(s). The plus sign tells the search engine that acertain word or phrase is required in the search results, and a minus sign indicates that aword or phrase must be absent in the search results.

Note: A phrase must be contained within quotation marks. Leave no spaces between theplus or minus sign and the term.

Example: +photoshop -elements will return only documents that contain the wordphotoshop and do not contain the word elements.


Use field searches

Field searches allow you to create searches for words that appear in a specific part of a document. A field search can be performed on body text (body:), title text (title:), description (desc:), keywords (keys:), or URL (url:). The field name should be inlower-case and immediately followed by a colon. There should be no spaces between thecolon and the search term.

Note: The field searches can only be followed by a word or phrase. Phrases must becontained within quotation marks.

Examples:
title:"reader download"
desc:red-eye
keys:acrobat
body:muse
url:adobe.com/products/


Use wildcards

Wildcard searches can expand the number of matches for a particular request. The *character is used as the wildcard character.

For instance, searching for licens* will find the words license, licensing, and licenses. Searching for *graph will find the words photograph, paragraph, and anyother word that ends with graph.

Wildcards may be combined with the standard plus (+) and minus (-) modifiers, quotes forphrases, and field search specifiers.

Examples:
convert* pdf
media encod*
jcr:content.serverDown: We're sorry, we are unable to perform a search right now, please try again later.
jcr:content.title: Adobe.com
